Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Nurturing student learning by bringing relevant academic content to the consumer
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project is aimed at developing a web-based system that enables students, educators and parents to discover standards aligned K-12 educational resources that meet the strengths, needs and passions of students. The universe of K-12 educational resources has rapidly expanded in the last few years through the abundance of education technology products (including mobile applications). Though mobile applications and online educational content have high levels of engagement with students, they are not considered as curricular learning because of their unstructured nature. In a study by the Gates foundation, 71% of high school dropouts reported lack of interest by 9th and 10th grade and the study recommends engaging learners through real-world, experiential learning. Students who drop out of school do not qualify for 90% of available jobs. The solution developed through this SBIR Phase 1 will empower students with choices and variety in content, and will be aligned to student's passion, e.g., choice of sound engineering videos and/or music-based math for an aspiring musicians. The use of such technology which is standards aligned and tuned to the student's passion is expected to improve student graduation rates and associated economic growth for the communities at large.

The Phase 1 SBIR will provide a web-based system that is a first-of-its-kind integrated and personalized learning solution that can curate various types of educational resources for students and teachers and present these resources in a manner that is tuned to student's passions. It will provide school districts and families a sustainable and cost effective solution to make efficient use of limited resources and budgets to procure standards aligned content that are highly engaging to students. The resulting system will be organized as a consumer application that can facilitate the discovery of standards-aligned educational resources that work with the strength and the pace of a student, and personalize learning at the student level. This system will enable, ALL students, regardless of socioeconomic status to have access to relevant educational materials both inside and outside the classroom. An initial alpha launch, a pilot study and analytical data gathering involving teachers and students will be conducted over Phase 1 to study the efficacy of the developed solution. The goal of this research is to verify the system features, the ease of use and understand if Phase 1 activities result in a prototype that offers technical feasibility to solve the attempted problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF SBIR Phase 1 award developed Ecos, a cutting-edge STEM discovery platform. Ecos is designed to reduce the burden on teachers accessing high-quality standards-aligned digital STEM content that is otherwise fragmented among websites, apps, and outlets. The proposing firm, Pedagogy World DBA K12Nest, designed Ecos to revolutionize K-12 STEM education by seamlessly integrating these very disparate resources and aligning them to standards for easy incorporation into everyday instruction.


Phase 1 research indicated that teachers spend between 2 and 8 hours each week looking online for digital educational content. Given the rigor and depth of knowledge demanded from newer standards like Common Core State Standards (CCSS) and Next Generation State Standards (NGSS), the problems of accessing quality content is further compounded by challenges in offering a variety of engaging learning experiences in instructional delivery.


Ecos research involved understanding the pain of K-12 stakeholders (teachers, students, and administrators) accessing high-quality STEM content. The project also researched problems faced by small-scale content providers serving the K-12 market in getting discovered by a national pool of educators and students. This research was performed through customer discovery interviews as part of I-Corp and Beat the Odds Bootcamp programs, as well with user testing over closed alpha and beta pilots.


Research and technology development of a Phase 1 prototype resulted in the Ecos open-beta prototype, launched for the public in August 2016 with math and science curricular content. Content included videos, mobile applications, worksheets, lesson plans, and games aligned to CCSS and NGSS.


Stellar, high-quality K-12 content from sources like Khan Academy, Discovery Education, EngageNY, EOL, Concord Consortium, and Illustrative Mathematics, as well as paid content like mobile applications, courseware from small- and medium-scale providers like eTAP, Readorium, and Start Engineering were included in the Phase 1 prototype.


As a result of the evaluation process, Ecos has collected vital curricular and quality data on every educational resource in 75 variable fields. These include:

(a) descriptive elements that include primary and secondary subjects, grade, skills, and content type;

(b) curricular alignment to standards and the degree to which the resources align to various standards;

(c) instructional coherence data showing how the content demonstrates relevance to standards for instructional purposes;

(d) data showing various assessments the resources employ and the extent to which these resources are grade, subject, and standards relevant;

(e) data of resources’ support for diverse learners as evidenced by compliance to Universal Design for Learning (UDL) principles;

(f) data on usability of the resource.


Pilots with a global pool of educators were conducted to study the feasibility and efficacy of the prototype. Ninety percent of alpha-pilot respondents said Ecos was very easy to navigate. Nearly all (91%) of respondents believed the completed Ecos product would reduce the time spent looking for resources by an average of 80%. A majority (73%) of respondents said that the complete Ecos product would replace their current first choice of search engine to find resources, and the “key differentiator” of Ecos was Ecos Bundles in 90% of the responses. Subjects responded particularly well to the prospect of "Differentiation,” with one Colorado teacher noting, “I can look at progression. This is differentiation on a platter. I have only one [opportunity] to teach both advanced kids and kids who don't get it, and Ecos can make it work.”

Broader Societal Outcomes

For Teachers: Ecos saves vast amounts of teachers’ time in searching online for high-quality STEM content by offering standards-aligned curricular choices and suggestions for classroom applications. Further, STEM videos like “Nanoparticles” from NSF’s Science360 have also been incorporated, so teachers can go beyond their current level of STEM expertise with ease and incorporate cutting-edge STEM in their classrooms.

Adoption of NGSS: The new NGSS are highly complex. Teachers and content providers must not only understand the new standards but also figure out how to teach in compliance with these standards. The existence of Ecos as an independent third-party to evaluate and provide alignment of content to NGSS is of benefit to content providers, and providing NGSS-aligned content for instruction is of benefit to educators.

Impact on STEM education: Ecos puts advanced STEM concepts directly in the hands of teachers and students in bite-sized chunks with room for exploration. With access to a variety of high-quality STEM resources, the Ecos team hopes to inspire students in STEM in both fundamental science and advanced innovations.
